text: So good morning.
Morning.
Thank you for joining me today.
You're welcome.
So if you can just take me a bit
through your career path up until today.
Whoa. How far do you want to go back?
Wherever you want to start?

Okay, well,
I didn't intend to go into tech.
I was a pre-med major and
during college I went home

and visited with some family friends
and job shadowed them.

And at the end of the job shadowing,
one of the doctors looked at me

and he said, “So
what do you think?” I'm like, “I'm all in.
I can't wait for med school.”

And literally he was a good mentor of mine
and he looked at me and he said,

“You're not,
this isn't the right career for you.”

And he said, “Why don't you go back to
college and go explore some other things?”

So to make a long story short,
that's how I discovered computers,
in my senior year.

And so, I got really into programming
and then got into a combination

of programming and healthcare
and started out in healthcare consulting.

Then wanted to get a master’s degree
and so switched over

to telecommunications back
before there were any customers.

So, I think I predate you on that
because I started out
at Sprint PCS before we had any customers.

Started out as an Analyst One
and went all the way through the career

ladder and joined T-Mobile as a part
of the Sprint merger with T-Mobile.

And so, now I am the Vice President
of Digital Transformation,

building out all the future state
digital platforms for T-Mobile.
Oh, cool ride.
Yeah, it's fun.
And today, what makes you tick?

What gets you
excited on the day-to-day job?

I love the fact that I get to solve
big business problems
and make a real difference for people.

My why statement on why I'm doing
what I'm currently doing is,

I figured out that
I can make the biggest difference

to American lives
by eliminating bill shock once and forever
for our T-Mobile customers.

Then I could do volunteering
every single hour of my life.

So what we're doing is we're creating
what we call real-time billing,

which during the shopping
phase and all lifecycle

events, customers will be able to see
a real-time update of what their bill is

and be able
to even try out new promos and compare.

And this will help Americans be confident
in knowing that their bill shows up

exactly
the way that they expected it to be.

And they don't have that uncertainty about,
am I going to have some kind of increase

this month that might prevent me from
being able to pay for rent or buy food.
Very innovative.
We'll get back to that in a minute.

And so, let's dive a bit into T-Mobile,
but before that, tea or coffee?

Coffee. Okay.
Just to make sure we're aligned.
So can we still be friends?
Yes. Yeah, coffee is for me as well.
So let’s dive into T-Mobile a bit more.

So everybody by
now knows that T-Mobile is the un-carrier,

but can you explain a bit more of
what do we mean by un-carrier?

So the whole premise of the un-carrier
is that we put customers first
in absolutely everything we do.

And we even have a corporate objective
that says we love our customers.

We don't just sort of like them, we don't
just want to do business with them.
We actually want them

to feel like superstars
every single time they interact with us.

And so, all of our un-carrier
moves are to show that love to customers.

One of the latest ones that I personally
love is our un-carrier move around travel.

So I'm sure you're enjoying
all the free Wi-Fi in the planes.

An un-carrier is more technology,
more culture?
How do you see that within T-Mobile?
It has to permeate everything.

So un-carrier, even just an
external expression of love to customers.
It's also an internal expression.

And internally, what being un-carrier
means is looking at the way we do

everything to maximize value still for
both our shareholders and our customers.
And that’s where the tech comes in, right?

So on the tech front, being un-carrier
means that by putting the customer first

when it comes to technology,
we need to make sure that everything

is 100% secure, that it’s reliable and
that it’s really easy to do self-service.
So let's talk about technology just a bit.

So how are you working to be
the un-carrier

and be innovative
with Cloud, with your technology partners?

What are you looking for
when you are looking at your partners?

So when we're working with our partners,
we want to work with
folks like

AWS who put security first,
who put low latency first,

because again, it's not enough
to just be stable, those days are gone

now it's about how fast are you
and how secure are you for
every single transaction.

And when you would work
with partners like AWS, like Salesforce,

like Amdocs,
what do you demand of them to do

in order to be innovative and do real time
billing and be customer first?

So our approach of working with partners
is doing joint roadmaps.

So we want to be able to sit at the table
with our partners, explain

our business challenges in our own terms,
and then jointly innovate

on how we approach technical solutions
to solve those.

We often do this with multiple partners
in the room at the same time,
because we know that it takes an ecosystem

and no one partner can solve
absolutely everything.

But together,
we’re creating amazing solutions.

I understand
you recently also did a reorg.
Does that have to do

with this approach of the un-carrier
on one and technology on the other?

You mean that
I'm working in marketing now? Yes.
Oh, wow.
That was a day when I woke up,

the first day after the reorg and realized
that for the first time in my life

I wasn't working in technology,
I was working in marketing.

But I think it’s one of the most
innovative things that we did at T-Mobile,

in that by co-locating technology
with the business we’re so much,

it's funny, it's like a barrier went down
and we're so much closer to each other.

And they don’t feel weird about me
sitting in the same room with them,

ideating on their challenges
and bringing new solutions to them

and actually suggesting other things
we can do

for our customers,
that they hadn’t even occurred to them.

And now it's
as if I had always lived in marketing,
even though it's not even been a year yet.

And it works well, the organization know
how to work together.

Where do you see the major challenge
of working business and IT together?
There hasn't been a challenge.

The only thing that comes up sometimes
is, “Hey, should we split up IT

more and put it in more business units?”
And that I would guard against.

I don't think it's good
to completely decentralize.

I think technology does
need to be together for a reason

because you get economies of scale,
consistency on standard

standards,
all of those really important things.
But at the same time, having us close
to the business is equally important.

Where should Cloud and AWS
play in that part?

In which part?
You want to join marketing too?
For sure.

It sounds like great fun,
but in order to accelerate the business

and IT transition together,
where do you see AWS driving that?
I see AWS playing in quite a few places.
So as you and I were chatting earlier,

I'm bringing together some key
platform players

that have very innovative products
like Amdocs, Salesforce, Adobe,
and I need AWS right there at the table

because all three of those players
are going to reside in AWS for me.
And we have to make sure that we’re

optimizing
how all three are set up for T-Mobile,

so that we have lightning fast speeds
and very secure transactions.

With everything going on and now you're
part of marketing in the business,

where do you think the industry will be
in five years from now, 10 years from now?

The telecom industry or technology
overall?

Let's do both. 
Do both?
Oh, that's a great question.
What do you think Hagai?

I think from what I see with the telecoms
we’re meeting is that most of the telcos

are moving from becoming communication
companies to technology companies.

And the ones that are moving
very fast up the value chain

from connectivity to connectivity plus,
which might be trivial, like adding

security, adding over the top,
they’re more successful and the ones

that will be even more successful
are the ones that are gonna drive

industrial IOT and 5G Edge and application
that will benefit the users.

I think I see T-Mobile
doing some of it already, of
basically bridging the digital divide

with broadband to the home and Project
10Million.
And I’m very excited to see what T-Mobile
will do with private network and Edge,

and we really hope
to be part of that journey.
Last question-
Seahawks or Chiefs?
Oh my god.
Hello, Chiefs all the way.

Thank you very much for your time today. 
Thank you, Hagai.
